ratings.comment: Took her class on The Tale of Genji. Engaging lecturer and is very clear about grading criteria. This is by no means an easy class, but if you do the reading and attend lectures, the work will not be too difficult.
She is a picky professor on absolutely random things, like citing a book with the date, and will give you a zero. The TA I had for her class, Max Kanne, was also absolutely terrible in the same way.

There are no formal tests or quizzes in this class, but there is a decent amount of reading. Most of the grade for this class comes from class recaps, write ups, and talks. Overall this class was very interesting and it is clear that professor Etcheverry cares and knows a lot about Japanese culture.

Charo is just an overall great person who clearly cares about her students. I had her as my discussion leader for The Art/Science of Human Flourishing, which was one of my favorite classes I've ever taken. All of the information was applicable and the assignments were very manageable. They emphasize the experience of the class rather than grades!

Charo is a wonderful professor overall. She's incredibly enthusiastic, well-spoken, and caring. And while she is a generous grader, her class is by no means a cakewalk. She isn't afraid to assign a lot of reading, and expects a lot out of students. Put in the work, come to class, show you care, and you'll do great.

Professor D'Etcheverry is amazing! She knows what she is teaching and handles uncomfortable topics in some books with dignity, understanding and respect. Her lectures are extremely engaging and informative and will grab your attention if you are in class. She is one of the best professors on campus and I highly recommend taking a course with her.

The grading is contract-based, but the professor does give you some chance to earn extra credit. The coursework feels somewhat intensive with 2 papers, 2 talks, weekly posts, storytelling, and lecture participation. Professor Charo responds quickly via email. She also modified her schedule multiple times to set aside some time for office hours.

Charo was nice and actively tried to help students succeed in the course. The main problem though was that instead of actually teaching about Asian culture, she instead taught about how to write essays and do homework. This felt like a basic English course, where bibliographies and formatting was more important than the subject matter.

She taught every day how to do homework in lecture instead of the Asian culture I was expecting. The various tasks she assigns are very demanding. This elementary course cost me a semester of study time, and it took me more time to study this class than I took my major class! Now that the semester is over, I don't know what I've learned!

Charo was a great professor for this class. The class has no exams, only weekly posts, and a few papers. There is a very clear grading criteria, and if you don't get it right the first time she tells you what area could use improvement and gives you another chance to fix it for full credit. There are some hefty weekly readings, but also some movies
The biweekly Global Badgers seminar for the International Learning Community is small, low pressure, and fun. Charo is understanding and caring and leads interesting discussions and field trips.

Contract grading is great as you know what you need to do for an A on day one. The presentation responses are tedious but manageable and the group project isn't too much work. The lectures are pretty abstract and she can get sidetracked but she is really enthusiastic and passionate about the course material. Super nice and accessible to students.

Prof Etcheverry was super nice and helpful. It was contract graded, which means if you do a certain amount of work it will qualify you for that grade. I thought this layout was stressful, in addition to the very unorganized canvas site. The class material was interesting, but I'd recommend waiting until in-person classes return.

This class was really cool and satisfied a Communication B credit. Our class was on a grading contract, so basically if you do all the work to a decent standard, youll get an A. The canvas page was kind of hard to operate, so just ask questions if youre confused. Overall really liked this class and the professor!

Charo is a great choice for if you just need Comm B. She cares about the material, and uses contract grading so you get an A if you just do the homework. The only tedious thing in her class is that there are a lot of focus points on citing work, so the class feels more focused on that instead of the actual readings and ideas from asian studies.
Very enthusiastic about the course material. She is also extremely helpful inside and outside of the class and works with students to help them improve their writing and grades. Highly reccomend

The most committed instructor I had the pleasure of taking a course with. She will give you all the information you ever need if a topic interests you and will make sure that you succeed in class. She grades decently enough, kinda nit-picky but she won't harass you for it. The readings are long, yes, but read them and you will be rewarded greatly.

One of my favorite professors on campus; she faces her students with immense energy & enthusiasm. Although she is a tough grader, she offers a lot of feedback and WANTS to see you succeed. We've discussed much outside of class and even then she serves as a mentor and a friend, she really does want the best for her students.

She pretends that she is the most helpful and warm-hearted teacher in the world. She looks so nice but never explained the key points. She told you what to do and you did exactly what she asked. But every time she returned your essay with an undesirable grade. And she always points our new weakness in your essay that she has not said before.

She is just an amazing professor. I received a rather bad grade on the first essay assignment, she gave me a talk from which I was really inspired. It was a painful semester in her classical literature, but I did learn how to read. She is absolutely awesome
She is nice, but you have to read a lot. i would recommend this class if you like reading 20 pages of two articles and three chapters of the text book every week.

The best literature class I have ever had! The class is funny and the proefessor really makes me think. She teaches me how to read books and what literature is by reading " The Tale of Genji." She makes you know how history and politics background relate to a book in her class. And she is a pretty pretty nice and warm-hearted people. Take her !

Amazing professor. Grading was based on discussion attendance (lecture is optional), 3 essays, and a final exam. Used 7 books so it was a lot of reading but she has a great sense of humor to make boring books enjoyable. Final was super easy. So, I got an AB with a moderate amount of work.

Mrs. D'Etcheverry has always been my favorite teacher in the UW. Her lectures are amazing - interesting, sometimes comical and always passionate. You can tell she loves the material - it makes a difference. She's willing to listen and help. Fair grading (leaning towards the nice). Best in EAS Department in my opinion. Love her!
One of the best professors! Generous about grading, passionate about teaching and helpful in the office hour. I would definitlely take another class with her.

Very good professor. I love her class for her teaching style, with my only reason for frustration being that I'm not keeping up with readings. Have the stories read and be in class. Excessive note-taking not necessary, as she tests on general ideas and concepts. In addition, she sometimes shows movie clips at the start of class, which is fun!
Fantastic professor.  Care passionately for her subject matter and for her students. One of the best professors at UW.  The course itself somewhat muddy, not sure how much I actually learned.

She is knowledge and always willing to help, gives detailed suggestions on paper revision. She replies email very fast. She speaks very fast~I'm sure that's because she is so smart~Reading assignment is really a lot(especially for those non-English native speakers...), it's a little like literature class though it's not.

I loved Charo,but didn't care much for the class. Her lectures are captivation and she is a great speaker,however I feel I learned very little about Japanese Civilization and a great deal about Japanese Literature. Her focus is clearly literature,and I think labeling this course "Japanese Civilization"as extremely misrepresentative of what's taught

Loved her, loved her, loved her. Such a sweet lady. Very funny, very lively. She spoke so well you'd swear she'd rehearsed the lecture word-for-word (of course not the case). Very knowledgeable. Made a potentially dry subject interesting.

She took what might have been a very dry ethnographic course and made it interesting by relating stories about her adventures in Japan and by challenging her students to critically consider the material. The course reading complemented the curriculum very well, and was a joy to read. I wish more classes gave credit for reading Murakami.
She's fun..she can make a boring class interesting..work is ok i guess..not too hard
Good Class, a little too much reading but tests are very straaight forward.  Must go to class but basically if you do you will get better than a BC.  Easy 3 credit class if you put in any work.
Discussions were very engaging.  Classes seemed mainly like a discussion despite being a lecture.  EAsian253 was a low-workload class.
She's SUPER fun :D
A relatively easy course.  Lots of reading, but quizzes and tests were very easy provided the reading had been done.  Had a grand total of 3 pages worth of papers to write all semester.
